Avoid accessing possibly-undefined InfiniBand field in GDR (#416)

Summary:
In case of a Work Completion (WC) that resulted in an error, only some fields are "valid": status, wr_id and qp_num. In particular opcode isn't valid, and yet we were inspecting it to determine whether it was a send or recv request (and increase the corresponding pointer). In case of error, the opcode was neither send nor recv and this triggered an assert. The "solution" is to store the opcode ourselves, separately, in a map indexed by wr_id. We already have such a map, hence we just inster a new field into it.

Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/416

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D32720035

Pulled By: lw

fbshipit-source-id: bef94c060f6536bc334ef87f536fb05d7bbc1eb1

Fix send queue being undersized in IBV (#414)

Summary:
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/414

When creating a queue in InfiniBand one must specify its maximum capacity, but by mistake we were assuming that in IBV the send queue only held RDMA_WRITE requests, and had forgotten about the SEND requests (for acknowledgements). This caused the queue to be undersized, thus for some of our `post` calls to fail unexpectedly (because we were convinced the queue still had capacity and thus asserted that the call couldn't fail).

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D32102685

fbshipit-source-id: c304d91f2619c73a4b52b054bab620de7553b37a

Fix dangling references in IBV&GDR when stashing work requests

Summary:
An InfiniBand queue can only hold so many pending requests (we configure its capacity when we create it) and if we were to post more requests to it then it would fail. Which is why we keep track of this and stash excess requests and only submit them when some previous ones finish.

However, when stashing, we were either storing a _reference_ to a _stack-allocated_ `send_wr` or `recv_wr` or, more subtly, we were storing these by value but they contained a pointer to a stack-allocated `sge`. Thus when we tried to submit these values to InfiniBand after stashing them they'd be filled with garbage, leading to a lot of very funny errors.

The solution is to simply put the data we need into another structure, which we pass by value, and build the `send_wr`, `recv_wr` and `sge` on demand just before they're needed.

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D32102686

Fix transport benchmark requiring CUDA (#407)

Summary:
Transports are CPU-only, thus the transport benchmark was requiring `tensorpipe` but not `tensorpipe_cuda`. However, for no good reason, it was including the `channel_registry.cc` file, which tried to include CUDA channels, which then couldn't be found at linking.

Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/407

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D30639385

Pulled By: lw

fbshipit-source-id: b2a8df01ed3ae004d67735f9c1b711107e93ee77

Make listeners return an address even when closed (#406)

Summary:
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/406

In D30220352, as I was enabling the automatic SHM address assignment in PyTorch (see D30158584 (https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/commit/e45b2338d0a31192a7e413f3fbbfa7fd90504a37)), I encountered failures in the faulty RPC agent, because it was closing the listener and/or the context very early and _after that_ still requesting the listener's address. This was failing, for example because the file descriptor at that point was closed.

I added tests for these scenarios, and fixed our transports, by having them retrieve and cache the address during init.

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D30541085

fbshipit-source-id: 62fc947f970e9540f70dfe70efb502218234dcae

Allow automatic address selection for SHM (#403)

Summary:
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/403

Linux supports "autobind" for UNIX domain sockets, where the kernel automatically assigns an available abstract address, just like it does for IP ports. Until now users had to come up with ways to generate unique(-ish) identifiers to use as addresses, to avoid collisions, but with this feature it's now gone.

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D30158584

Remove dependency of transport benchmarks on CUDA (#404)

Summary:
Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/404

Transports are CPU-only but the transport benchmark depends on options.cc which depends on channel_registry.cc which depends on tensorpipe_cuda.h which depends on CUDA. We can move stuff around to fix this.

This was causing build problems with CMake.

fbshipit-source-id: 078ee0cc80a9088fe11a4f4391f97e9c76b58a44

Make CUDA stuff stack on top of CPU one

Summary:
This is where things get serious. This diff does a few things:
- it creates a new `config_cuda.h.in` file, and moves there the flags for CUDA channels
- it _drops_ the `TENSORPIPE_SUPPORTS_CUDA` flag, because now it's up to the user to know whether they have compiled TP with CUDA support or not (there's no introspection/"autodiscovery")
- it removes a few old includes in `core`
- it moves all CUDA-specific includes from `tensorpipe.h` to `tensorpipe_cuda.h` (and stops `tensorpipe_cuda.h` including `tensorpipe.h`)
- it does _not_ update the build system because not much needs to be done in CMake, since PyTorch will not (yet?) split the TP agent into a CPU and a CUDA part, hence they do not yet need two separate CMake targets
- it changes _our_ tests and benchmarks (which, in a sense, are our own "self" usages)

Reviewed By: beauby

Differential Revision: D28866035

fbshipit-source-id: 83042f1e304f8ec28ef7cc1284c9da894517f507

Introduce tensorpipe_cuda.h

Summary: So far this header does nothing. But we need it to exist so that we can migrate PyTorch. Once that's done, we can actually move stuff into this header. (All of this is because we cannot do atomic changes across both TensorPipe and PyTorch).

fbshipit-source-id: f9045f2d5e42f4389469e735e6f734b496580fb5

Lift all-to-all restriction in channel selection. (#376)

Summary:
Before support for sender-specified target devices and XDTT, we
assumed that the target device type was the same as the source device
type, which allowed us to pick a channel based solely on the source
device type. This forced us to ensure a given channel connected all
pairs of devices that it supported.
Now that we always gather the target device (either from the sender or
from the receiver), that assumption is lifted, and hence the
restriction can be lifted as well.

Pull Request resolved: https://github.com/pytorch/tensorpipe/pull/376

Reviewed By: lw

Differential Revision: D28070607

Pulled By: beauby
